title: Python Basics 101
description: Test your knowledge of Python fundamentals.

questions.text: What is the output of the following code?
questions.explanation: In Python 3, the division operator / always returns a float, even if the result is a whole number.

questions.text: What will be the output of this slicing operation?
questions.explanation: Slicing includes the start index (1) but excludes the end index (4). So it takes elements at indices 1, 2, and 3.

questions.text: Which of the following is an immutable data type?
questions.explanation: Tuples are immutable sequences, meaning their elements cannot be changed after creation. Lists, Dictionaries, and Sets are mutable.

questions.text: What is the correct way to format a string in Python 3.6+?
questions.explanation: All options are valid ways to format strings, but f-strings (Option A) are the most modern and preferred way in Python 3.6+.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the `__init__` method in a class?

options.text: To initialize a new instance of the class

questions.explanation: `__init__` is the constructor method in Python. It is automatically called when a new object (instance) of a class is created.

questions.text: What is the output of the following code?

codeSnippet.code:
a = [1, 2, 3]
b = a
c = [1, 2, 3]
print(a is b, a is c)

questions.explanation: `a` and `b` point to the same object in memory, so `a is b` is True. `c` is a new list with the same content, but a different object in memory, so `a is c` is False.

questions.text: What is the result of this list comprehension?

codeSnippet.code:
nums = [x for x in range(5) if x % 2 == 0]
print(nums)

questions.explanation: `range(5)` generates 0, 1, 2, 3, 4. The condition `x % 2 == 0` filters for even numbers: 0, 2, 4.

questions.text: Which keyword is used to define an anonymous function?
questions.explanation: The `lambda` keyword is used to create small anonymous functions in Python.

questions.text: What happens if you try to access a dictionary key that doesn't exist using `[]`?
questions.explanation: Accessing a missing key with `[]` raises a `KeyError`. Using `.get('b')` would return `None`.

questions.text: In a `try-except-else` block, when does the `else` block execute?

options.text: When the finally block is missing

questions.explanation: The `else` block in a try-except statement is executed only if no exceptions were raised in the `try` block.
